A keen footballer who lost both legs in a horror crash just seven months ago is getting closer to the biggest goal of his life. 
Walking down the aisle on his wedding day. 
Estate agent Shaun Whiter was helping a pal fix a flat tyre when a hit and run driver smashed into them last July. 
Shaun, 28, lost four pints of blood and had to have both his legs amputated below the knee. 
But a remarkable recovery has meant he already has prosthetic legs and is walking with the aid of a crutch. Read More Shaun Whiter with his fiancee Charlotte Way (Photo: Daily Mirror) Shaun lost both his legs as he was helping a pal change a tyre (Photo: Daily Mirror) 
Now he’s aiming to walk out of the church with his “rock” – bride Charlotte Way, 28 – on their big day in July. 
“I’m getting there,” says Shaun who played for Newmarket Town FC. “I’m so pleased with how far I’ve come. I got my prosthetic legs just before Christmas. 
“They’re very heavy. It’s hard, like walking with stilts – but the thought of walking down the aisle has kept me going. Shaun Whiter in his football team line up 
“I’m using one crutch. The plan is to walk unaided, then I’ll be out attacking the world.” 
His fiancee Charlotte took a year out from work to care for him and set up a JustGiving page which raised more than £100,000 to pay for his ­rehabilitation. 
“I’m so grateful to everyone for their support – family, friends and the football community, from Cambridge United , Ipswich Town and my old team Newmarket.” Jan Adamec who ran into Shaun (Photo: SWNS) 
“Now I can’t wait for our wedding day. The church has cobbled floors so I will need to learn to walk on that. 
Shaun, who needs treatment four times a week, admits he has his “down moments”. But he says: “Charlotte picks me up. She makes me feel things are possible.” 
In September, driver Jan Adamec, 40, was jailed for 40 months for the crash, which left Shaun’s pal Joey Abbs with serious leg injuries. Shaun says he can't wait for his wedding day (Photo: Daily Mirror) 
Shaun still drives past the spot where it happened, not far from his home in Newmarket. 
But the prefers not to dwell on the past. “I’ve joined a new football club with other amputees now,” he says. “And I can’t wait to run again.” Like us on Facebook
